abstract.text: Update your watchOS app project to adopt SwiftUI, WidgetKit, and other modern features.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: TN3157: Updating your watchOS project for SwiftUI and WidgetKit

inlineContent.text: Since the debut of Apple Watch, watchOS app development has the following important milestones:
In 2015, watchOS 1 was released, together with WatchKit and ClockKit.
In 2020, watchOS 7 was released. WatchKit storyboards were deprecated. New developments use SwiftUI.
In 2022, Xcode 14 was released. It removes the support of creating a new WatchKit storyboard, and introduces single-target watchOS app.
In 2023, watchOS 10 was released. ClockKit complications were deprecated, and the replacement is WidgetKit complications.
SwiftUI is cross-platform and provides many features unavailable in WatchKit, such as
and

. WidgetKit complications support Smart Stack in watchOS 10. Making a watchOS app single-target simplifies the project configuration. If you have an existing watchOS app, now is the time to get rid of the deprecated WatchKit storyboards and ClockKit complications, and adopt the modern features.
This technote uses the following terminology to refer a watchOS app with different characteristics:
A
dependent
app relies on its companion iOS app to function.
An
independent
app works when the paired iPhone isn’t nearby, or when its companion iOS app isn’t installed. It may or may not have a companion iOS app.
A
dual-target
app has a watchOS app target and a WatchKit extension target for its core functionality.
A
single-target
app has only a watchOS app target for its core functionality.
A
watch-only
app doesn’t have a companion iOS app.
Both single-target and dual-target apps can have other targets. For example, you can add targets to implement widgets or app intents for a single-target or dual-target app.
Apple Watch users expect that the apps to just work, even when they don’t have their iPhones with them. If you have a dependent watchOS app, consider making it independent. See
for details.

If your watchOS app is dual-target, convert it to single-target. This simplifies the project configuration and eliminates any confusion about where to embed a resource or apply an entitlement. Single-target watchOS apps work on watchOS 7 and later. For more information, see

A single-target watchOS app requires watchOS 9.2 or later to inherit the HealthKit permissions granted to its companion iOS app. If your app uses HealthKit and needs to support earlier versions of watchOS, keep your dual-target app configuration.
To convert a dual-target app to a single target:
Create a complete back up for your project so you can roll back if something goes wrong.
In Xcode’s Project navigator, select the project, then choose Xcode > Editor > Validate Settings.
Select the “Project
- Upgrade
to a single-target watch app” checkbox if unselected, then choose Perform Changes to let Xcode do the conversion.

If you use storyboards, go through all the interface controllers, and change the class module to the watchOS app module. To do that, select an interface control,  and choose View > Inspectors > Identity; in the inspector, set the Class field in the Custom Class section.
Remove the files only relevant to the WatchKit extension, such as the extension’s
Clean up your project by re-organizing the groups and files in Xcode’s Project navigator.
The second step removes the WatchKit extension target and moves its associated source code and resources to the watchOS app target. At the code level, it replaces
and
with
and
. It also changes the
of the watchOS app target as needed. For example, if your watchOS app has a complication, it moves the complication controller class, which is specified with
, to the watchOS app target, and adds the
and
entries to the watchOS app’s
You now have a single-target watchOS app project. Verify that everything works well by running the project on an Apple Watch.
To adopt SwiftUI lifecycle in your watchOS app, start by adding a SwiftUI app (
) struct:
If you need to run the
methods in the SwiftUI lifecycle, use
to connect the app delegate to the SwiftUI app. Otherwise, remove the delegate class.
If you still use
and need to run the extension delegate methods in the SwiftUI lifecycle, migrate
to
To migrate your WatchKit storyboard, rewrite the interface with SwiftUI. Alternatively, consider adopting SwiftUI incrementally by using
to host SwiftUI views in your WatchKit interface controllers.
To migrate a ClockKit complication to WidgetKit:
Create a widget to replace the ClockKit complication. See
for details.
Implement
in the complication controller class to migrate the ClockKit complication. See
for details.
When the ClockKit complication doesn’t have a descriptor, the system passes a descriptor with the default identifier (
) to
. Ignore the descriptor and return a
object with the appropriate widget kind.

content.text: From a watch-only app to a watchOS app with a companion iOS app

inlineContent.text: SwiftUI and WidgetKit are both cross-platform. If you have a watch-only app, you might want to enhance the watchOS app by adding an iOS companion app, and have the iOS app share SwiftUI views and widgets with the watchOS app.
After adding an iOS companion app and publishing it to the App Store, you can’t roll back to a watch-only app.
To add an iOS companion app to an existing watch-only app project:
Create a complete back up for your project so you can roll back if something goes wrong.
In Xcode, select your project in the Project navigator, then add a new iOS app target.
Select the iOS app target from the Targets list, click the Signing & Capabilities tab, then
from the Team pop-up menu and enter a
. Be sure that the iOS app’s bundle ID is the prefix of the watchOS app’s bundle ID. For example, if the watchOS app’s bundle ID is
, the iOS app’s bundle ID must be
Select the General tab, then under Frameworks, Libraries, and Embedded Content, add the watchOS app as an embedded content of the iOS app.
Confirm that the
key in the watchOS app’s
is set to the bundle ID of the iOS app.

You now have a project that has an independent watchOS app with a companion iOS app. By default, Xcode doesn’t install the iOS app when running the watchOS app. If you’d like to change the behavior, add the
entry to the
of the watchOS app, then set its value to
First published.
